name: Gloom Razor of the Hin: Rogue 24 / Fighter 6 / Divine Champion 10
author: grizzled_dwarflord

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
There is a footnote in the annals of halfling history that reference an ancient line of warlike halflings.  Chief amongst them were the Gloom Razors, divine warrior scouts who were unmatched in combat.  Dauntless, fearless, these Hin Warlords were the premier knights of the Gloom Brigade, for they dwelt in the Gloaming, the twilight, but this is just a footnote in the old Hin annals, and likely nothing more than the fancy musings of a halfling historian deep in his cups….
 

Peerless in combat and virtually unhittable, the Gloom Razor launches a terrifying assault from darkness, with 6 attacks per round, 12d6 sneak per blade, coupled with Epic Weapon Specialization, Crippling Strike, Improved Knockdown and/or Called Shot to shred your opponent to bits. 
 
Title: Gloom Razor of the Hin
AKA: The Shire Wraith
Class: Rogue 24 / Fighter 6 / Divine Champion 10
Profession: Commando-Hitman-Mechanic

Strengths
·       Epic Dodge and Undispellable Self Concealment 50%
·       High AC
·       Very Good AB for Dual-wielder with high rogue levels
·       With a small bump to Dex, can eventually set Epic Traps
·       Disable all traps
·       UMD for Wand and Scroll Casting
·       Versatile Offensive Toolkit – can launch 12d6 sneak with Crippling Strike, and can supplement it with Called Shot or IKD 6 times per round.
·       The build matures early and often
 
Weaknesses
·       Fort Save, while respectable, still susceptible to Dev Crit (if the enemy can connect)
·       Will Save.  While pretty respectable for a finesse build, can still be a concern
·       Beware of IGMS trebuchets
·       No HiPS safety blanket
 
Combat Strategies
·       From a stealthed position, launch an IKD on your opponent.  If successful, begin to land Called Shot: Arm attacks, combined with Crippling Strike, and when your opponent gets back on his feet, if he gets back on his feet, he will have jello arms.  You’ll be able to knock down again, which he will be more susceptible since his strength will be lowered.
·       Mine the combat field with traps to disable and weaken your opponent
·       Never fight fair
 
Sneak Attack Generation
·       From your initial Stealth position
·       Source of Invisibility (Potion, Wand, Item, Scroll)
·       Corner Stealth – running behind a corner or object that interrupts line of sight and then re-enter stealth mode
·       Flanking – allowing a party member to tank
·       More Flanking – use scroll or wand (or item) casting to create summons to give you flanking opportunities
·       Improved Knockdown – every flurry is a sneak on a knock-downed opponent
 
Similar Builds:
·       Halfling Commando by Xylophone: This is a slinger with no SC V or dual-wielding and significantly lower melee AB
 
·       Drowkiller: Human and much lower AB and lower saves
 
·       Martial Rogue:  Less Sneak, much lower AB, no dual-wielding or SC V
 
·       Shadow Sword: A TyrTemplar special, but lacks Crippling Strike, over 80 skill points less, no IKD or Called Shot, and doesn’t use sexy kukris
 
·       And then Mick Dagger’s well-considered Halfling Champion: Similar, but lacks SC V and Crippling Strike, less skill points, and doesn’t get Epic Dodge until Lvl 32.  In it’s favor it gets 1 higher AB, 1 higher AC, and more HP.  But still a much different build since he focuses on Discipline to go toe to toe with strength builds.
 
·       And then there is my own slew of Fighter/Rogue/CoT’s: Death’s Rival, The Last Great Bounty Hunter, and the Incredible Fighting Rogue of War, but they’re all Dwarves, so… I won’t bother posting links for those.
 
Builder’s Commentary
While I hesitate to call anything the “quintessential” build of something, this is fairly close to being one to represent the halfling rogue warrior clan.  There are many varied combinations of these classes – a testament to the versatility of this combo – but somehow this one manages to be different.  Of course, when you play this game long enough at some point you feel like you’re “jumping the shark” when building any kind of class combo anymore.  Many (me included) will often argue the value and investment of something like Self Concealment V since it is such a huge investment – 5 feats – and coming at the expense of other things that you would like to see your Rogue have (Epic Will, Slippery Mind, Epic Fort, Great Dex’s, Improved Sneaks or Epic Skill Foci).  Indeed, I remade this same character and removed the SC feats and achieved an unbuffed dualwielding AB of 44, which is outstanding for no WM or RDD levels while still retaining 24 Rogue levels. 
 
But there is still something sexy about SC V.  It’s baked in.  It’s permanent.  There’s no mitigation for it (save Blindfighting).  If the enemy’s first attack is an IKD, and he lands the hit, Epic Dodge makes it miss.  His second attack is now coming at 5 lower AB, which is like adding 5 to your AC.  Assuming he can still land that, Self Concealment takes over and now his hit is half as likely to miss.  Epic Dodge, coupled with high AC and SC feats, makes you nigh untouchable. 
 
Kukri’s were taken because they’re far sexier than daggers, and they can be keened and have a higher crit range.  However, Improved Crit is not taken because of the diminishing return on that investment.  Still, you could drop Called Shot, or Iron Will, if you feel you must have it.  I don’t think it adds much in a build like this.
 
I rarely take Called Shot in a non-archer build, but it works in this one.  It’s a nice tool to have for both ranged and melee tactics, especially of the enemy is either to large to knockdown or has immunity/discipline resistance. 
 
While I invested points in Discipline, you may find yourself not needing it and rely on Epic Dodge and Concealment (and KD Immunity) to avoid the best attack sequence from your enemies.  If you’re swarmed by more than two opponents with such attacks, you may reconsider that decision though.  Just know that enemies with Disarm/Improved Disarm may have a leg up on you, especially if they’re using medium or large weapons.
 
Spellcraft was cross-classed (yes, you have that many skill points) to help out in the saves department (+4 extra against spells).
 
Finally, there is something satisfying in how well the build matures.  It gradually and consistently becomes stronger, faster, better, and never seems to lack.  In fact, there is a sweet spot from Level 27 to Level 33 where, in a span of 6 levels, he grabs Epic Dodge, Crippling Strike, EWF, EWS, Epic Prowess, and SC I and SC II.  I do miss the days when one could take Epic Dodge at Level 21, but those days are gone.  Level 27 is as early as one can get it, and really should be the target one shoots for when building an Epic Dodger.

Hail Orion!  Your comments are always welcome.  In a way, without realizing (or maybe you did), you answered your own musings and ponderings.  The FighterX/RogueX/SD1 has been done to death, even more so that the Ftr/Rogue/CoT combo.  In fact, I think I even have a few still lingering around the ECB archives... the Zhentarim Field Agent comes to mind, though he is strength based.  But certainly there are many others if you run a filtered search for them.  But the Ftr/Rogue/SD really is a different build.  You have to expend two feats pre-epic so you'll lose Called Shot and either Toughness or Iron Will, and then of course the big drop in saves.  It would be more than 5 to each category.  I really think that's a different type of build.  Equally powerful, maybe even more deadly, but not as balanced, in my opinion.  

To illustrate, here's a version of exactly what you described by Mithdradates, dubbed simply Halfling.  Here are his saves:
Final Saves
  • Fortitude 21
  • Reflexes 31
  • Will 17

It's one thing to have a 17 Will, which is horrendous, but Will has always been the achilles heel of the Rogue.  But the 21 Fort is really low, too.  Implosions, Petrifications, Dev Crit, etc.... HiPS is nice, but I don't think all Rogue-centric builds should require HiPS as a pre-req.  I think it's a different build accompanied by a slightly different style.  

Here's another:  Sneaking Death (who, incidentally, gets a lower AB with 1 weapon than the Gloom Razor gets with 2)
Saves:
  • Fort 21
  • Reflex 33
  • Will 17 (15 if Iron Will is not taken)
To answer the question you didn't ask:  Is there a quintessential version of a Halfling Ftr/Rogue/SD out there?  Maybe.  Maybe not.  It may require more study.  Does that answer your question?

posts.author: Orion

One other thought that comes to mind, and it was really interesting to me, is when I read through Mithdradates's build that GDL linked, how Mithdradates suggested power attack/improved power attack could be a potential solution to improve damage for those dex based rogues facing critical and sneak immune opponents.

For me power attack/improved power attack is like the neglected ugly duckling, I just hate the loss of AB, but really I should be making use of this ability on my dexterity builds more when the AB is high enough. Its just something I hadn't thought of for a dexterity build, I've been going down the WS/EWS route to buff up damage.

It might mean those Rogue/CoT/SD builds that Mick Dagger and Grimnir have referenced might not actually need WS/EWS after all? 

Critical and sneak immune opponents tend to be annoying golems and undead, and fingers crossed they are not particularly dextrous and their AC is low enough that power attack is useful for a dex'er. Dragons are going to be an issue, but they normally are for most classes. At least you can crit them.

Just a thought. Great discussion, very much appreciated.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
As this is the first! time I have done a serious Rogue build, I have been relying heavily on stuff from this guild.  Especially the trapping and other Rogue stuff.

What I find is that although really good, and solid advice with the trap setting, it is really only good for 2~3 times (because of the amount of traps needed).  Occassionally, I was able to "rob" some traps off of trapped chests, etc, but not as often as I would have liked to, in order to round out my trap arsenal.

Building new ones at low levels really was not a good option - I needed those skill points more, elsewhere.  To that, there was not all that many resources available to build with.

I agree that it seems very plausible to move the two-weapon fighting feats towards the "rear" of the build.  It was not really possible to go TWF with the AB so low in beginning levels.  I was fighting with 1 kukri and shield all of the time.

Anyway, now that I am over level 30, this build is super STRONG!  It is just unbelievably, massively OP for everything that gets in it's path!  To anyone who does play this, it is worth it to get through the initial struggle (what a grind!) for what awaits near the end!

I think the build really takes off when one can finally chuck the armor and shield for some good robes and ITWF.  AC goes way up (and stays up!), damage potential skyrockets, and things just crystalize.

This is a Rogue build.  It wants to be a Rogue. 

Impressive!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Putting 5-10 points in craft trap can be very high value for those early levels.
With Int 14 -> modified 7 craft trap means a 35% chance to craft a minor fire/electrical trap (DC 20), modified 12 means a 60% chance.
Can buff it further with a Fox's cunning potion, or items which add to the craft trap skill.
There is 10% component loss chance but only if you fail your roll, this means 90% of failed rolls you get to re-roll. 
So once you hit about 25% chance of crafting a trap I wouldn't worry so much about losing components, just keep pressing that craft trap button
Minor holy traps are fantastic against undead opponents, have no DC for full damage, and only require DC 15, so even a 6 int half-orc without investment in the skill can make more minor holy traps than components lost. They are also party friendly, and I have set these in the middle of combat to good effect as well. 
Modified craft trap 19 with items/buffs is a nice target to aim for for what I believe to be a 25% chance to craft deadly fire/electrical traps.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I did, initially try to create some Traps - with some crystals that I found (was in some caves by a nearby keep...;) )

I failed miserably to make anything out of them.  I think from the 3 crystals I found, I only managed to get 1 trap out of it, and that trap "disappeared" with the first kobold.

Meh.

Kind of weened me from doing this.  I think if one wants to be a Trap Crafter, one should go all in, or just leave it.

I left it, and instead invested in Disarm (which allowed me to strip Traps off for my use, relieving me from having to find the materials and craft them).

I think Craft Trap is really an environmental "trick" - meaning if your environment does not have Traps readily available, then by all means invest in it.  But if Traps are readily available "in the wild" - I feel that Disarm and recovering Traps is just the better option.

They will always be available right in the area where one needs them.  Just recover them and set them, turning the enemies traps against them!

Anyway, I think it is a playstyle sort of thing.  Mine is mostly solo orientated, so...I really need to invest in skills that can increase survivability.

Well to each their own. I encourage keeping your mind open to new learning and experiences about craft trap. 
All three of you (GDL, Zanithar and Web) have seen my trapping in action. 
One of Zanithar's characters nearly died to my minor electrical traps after I dirtnapped (for another reason). 
It helps solving tricky low pre-epic problems if done well. 

Its less about whether craft trap is good / bad, its more about quality of life and making the most of your rogue.
The skill is there, its like whether you want to play that piano or guitar with 9 fingers or 10. 

You will want lots of components. One component is not enough. More like 10-25 components for minor traps. The more the better.
You can get that in the environment you play in.

You don't need huge investments in the skill. You should view 1 rank in the skill as large increase in your ability to make traps. 
As mentioned there is a 10% chance of component loss if you fail to make a trap. 

With zero ranks in craft trap->
Int 14 = modified craft trap 2 = 10% chance of making a DC 20 minor fire trap, 90% chance of failure, 9% chance of component loss. -> 1 component = half a trap
Drink a fox's cunning -> modified craft trap 4 = 20% chance of making same fire trap, 80% failure, 8% component loss -> 1 component = 2/3rd a trap
Equip craft trap +5 ring & fox's = modified craft trap 9 = 45% chance of making same trap, 55% failure, 5.5% component loss -> 1 component = 90% of a trap

So if you add like a few ranks it just makes life a bit easier to make those minor traps during those harder low levels. 
Its kind of like lore and appraise, you dont need those points but it helps with quality of life low pre-epic, then when you get to high pre-epic they arent really needed anymore.
If you have the components just make em.

1 minor trap is a waste of time especially if its a frost trap or something garbage like that. 
10-20 minor traps (200-400 damage) packs a punch and worth your effort.
25-30 minor traps (500-600 damage) should be enough to kill early pre-epic non-evasion bosses without getting your hands dirty at all. 

Again you want lots of components. 
Fire, electrical for most things. Holy for undead. Ignore others to start off with, waste of your time.
All you got to remember for a beginner like me. 

I actually stop making traps after minors. By the time I could use bigger traps, my character can do bigger and better things, like you have :)

There's a lot of cross-pollenation of skills and learning when in a party. We all have different ideas and ways of solving problems I'd encourage players to not go too heavy down the solo path and join up with others occasionally, who knows, you might learn something from them, and in my case, this craft trap concept was introduced to me by Zelcandra and I refined it in my own way.

Sorry GDL not trying to hijack your thread.

First, the whip. You'll lose 5 AB and 6 damage. The 5 AB consists of not taking a focus or epic focus in the weapon, costing you a combined -3; then, as the whip is a small weapon and this is a halfling, you'll get a further -2 penalty for dual-wielding it (you need tiny weapons for hins). Second, dropping fighter just makes it worse. To start with, you need a BAB of +7 before you can take CoT, which means your first 9 levels would have to be rogue, making early levelling much tougher. Then, you lose a bonus feat: fighter gets them at level 1, 2, 4, 6; CoT at 2, 4, 6, 8, 10. Weapon specialization (and therefore EWS) also has to fall, as only fighter can take it, so not only do you gimp the whip in your main hand, but now also your kukri in your off hand. Again, you'd have to delay when you take your bonus feats (making early levelling even harder) possibly into epic levels, which knackers epic feats.

I'll leave it there, at least for now.

A Halfling dual-wielding short swords would suffer -4 penalty to AB with both Ambidexterity and Two Weapon Fighting because the off-hand weapon is not "light" (a smaller size category than the wielder).  To have a penalty of only -2, the Halfling's off-hand weapon must be tiny (dagger or kukri).
